Diagnostic.Title: Use nameof to express symbol names
Use Length/Count property instead of Count() when available
Specify marshaling for P/Invoke string arguments
Non-constant fields should not be visible
Method has the wrong signature to be an entry point

Diagnostic.Message: Mark assemblies with NeutralResourcesLanguageAttribute

notifyEvent calls GetKeyboardState but does not use the HRESULT or error code that the method returns. This could lead to unexpected behavior in error conditions or low-resource situations. Use the result in a conditional statement, assign the result to a variable, or pass it as an argument to another method.
Member 'unInit' does not access instance data and can be marked as static
Non-constant fields should not be visible

Use the "Count" property instead of Enumerable.Count()

Member 'addKey' does not access instance data and can be marked as static

Change Fonts.Dispose() to call GC.SuppressFinalize(object). This will prevent derived types that introduce a finalizer from needing to re-implement 'IDisposable' to call it.
Member 'initForm' does not access instance data and can be marked as static
Change WindowOverlapWatchdog.Dispose() to call GC.SuppressFinalize(object). This will prevent derived types that introduce a finalizer from needing to re-implement 'IDisposable' to call it.

MaximizeWindowInOtherMonitor calls ShowWindow but does not use the HRESULT or error code that the method returns. This could lead to unexpected behavior in error conditions or low-resource situations. Use the result in a conditional statement, assign the result to a variable, or pass it as an argument to another method.

enumWindowsCallback calls GetWindowThreadProcessId but does not use the HRESULT or error code that the method returns. This could lead to unexpected behavior in error conditions or low-resource situations. Use the result in a conditional statement, assign the result to a variable, or pass it as an argument to another method.

enumWindowsCallback calls GetWindowText but does not use the HRESULT or error code that the method returns. This could lead to unexpected behavior in error conditions or low-resource situations. Use the result in a conditional statement, assign the result to a variable, or pass it as an argument to another method.
